I've noticed the main reviews for Kuzu no Honkai mostly give it mediocre results, citing the fact that it appears to be mostly just 'scum for scum's sake'; i.e just to make the viewers feel bad for the sake of being bad. I'd like to rectify that.
Kuzu no Honkai/Scum's Wish is painful. There's no way around that. It's a show whose very premise is the pain of unrequited love and all the dregs and drama that come with that. Do I think that the painful nature of Scum's Wish is something that makes it quite a lot of the time relatively 'unenjoyable' to watch? Yes.Do I think that detracts from the value and 'good' of the show? Not at all. I'll attempt to explain why I think Scum's Wish is one of the best shows that deals with the nitty gritty pains of love, and why I think it deserves a lot more recognition than simply being branded 'depression porn' or 'popular for nothing'.



Story: 9/10



I'll attempt to avoid the majority of spoilers here, but the essence of me giving this such a high rating is the fact that Scum's Wish does, in fact, resolve it's painful initial premise. Not only that, but the long, drawn out, and painful road to that resolution is supremely done in a way that makes the ending make 'sense'. 


I've noticed a lot of shows, for better or for worse, tend to simplify people in love by having them forget, or quickly move past past misgivings and the like. Scum's Wish takes a very human approach in that people don't forget. People hold grudges, especially when it comes to something as nebulous as love. The main characters sometimes come to grips with the fact that their desires or actions are wholly antipithal to what they previously said or wanted, and sometimes they don't. The arbitrary nature of people in desperate love is just that, arbitrary. Mugi, Hanabi, Ecchan, Moka, 'Onii-chan', and Akane-sensei don't need their actions to be logical in order to be real. 


I've heard people say, regarding to one of the characters, that they can't understand why they'd do X, Y, or Z. And I feel like this is one of the relative downfalls of Scum's Wish, and why I wouldn't rate it a perfect 10. It heavily depends on being relatable to the viewer. The entire story, with all of its contrivances, rely on the viewer being able to understand and empathize, rather than sympathize, with what some of the characters are going through. I won't lie, I heavily empathized with a lot of the characters and that probably aided in my own view of the show, and I understand at the same time that people who have been uh, lucky enough, to not 'understand', may not see the show in the same light.


So while I understand that many people may find the story of Scum's Wish incomprehensible and purely depressing material for depressive's sake, I would contend that it very capably addresses what some could call the 'darker side' of love and romance. The pain, the betrayal, the envy, the passion, the loneliness. 


Does Scum's Wish's story play heavily on what are arguably the most depressing aspects of the human experience regarding love? Yes. Do I think that because of this, it's just depression porn? No, because it does in fact have quite a satisfying 'ending'. One that makes logical sense and shows quite a remarkable development on the part of the main characters if you look back on the series. 


The only real reason I'm not giving the story a full 10 is because of this emphasis on empathy, and also because the 'resolution' felt slightly too quickly wrapped up.



Art: 9/10



Not much to say here because it mostly relates to the manga, so I'll try to keep it succinct. 


I'm not sure if many other people pick up on this, but to me the main aspect of the show's design (reflected and picked up from the manga) are the main characters' eyes. I've joked with some friends who also watched the show that the eyes of the main characters always seem 'dead' in some way or another. There's something about the flat colouring of the eyes, mixed with the gradient colour shift towards black from whatever their normal eye colour is that makes each characters' eyes so charming. It's probably the most defining feature of Scum's Wish visually, from a character design point of view at least.


The other main thing to talk about are the scene transitions. Like the manga, Scum's Wish uses a transition of a fade to black using a variety of effects, most usually drops of black onto the screen that spread and eventually cover the whole screen. It's obvious that these are teardrops, spreading across a page of a part of the story. It's a really nice stylistic element that adds to each scene transition, no matter how it's used.


Just a final note about the animation in general; Lerche did a good job in maintaining the style of the manga. A lot of the colouring is flat, and the character designs are basically the same as the manga, and as such are on point. Not much to elaborate here.



Sound: 10/10


One of the few places I'll give Scum a full 10 score, is sound. The choices of OP and ED are utterly fantastic, especially in Sayuri's rendition of Heikousen, or Parallel Lines. The lyrics suit the show's story and characters so much that its practically a spoiler to talk about them, so I won't go into a lot of detail about that. But both OP and ED capture essential feelings to Scum's Wish, and pull it off really well to the point that hearing each song illicits a pang of 

feeling in your chest. Whatever that feeling is, is up to the viewer, but being so capable of heavily associating with the core essentials of Scum's Wish give it a perfect score in that department.


In terms of the sound and use of music throughout the show itself, again, it's pretty much perfect. It's usually orchestral to some degree, but there's some vocal pieces thrown in, and they're usually on point in portraying either what the scene is portraying, or what the underlying subtext of the scene is. That may sound confusing, but as a little spoilery example, the music that usually plays during some of the more 'explicit' scenes between Mugi and Hanabi, are not happy or passionate at all. The moderately somber, minor tone reflects the fact that this is still a relationship of convenience between the two. Long drawn out strings are practically perfect in conveying the combating emotions of loneliness, desire, passion, and pain.



Characters: 10/10



This is probably the most contentious part about Scum's Wish. As I've mentioned in my scoring of the story, the experience of the characters all heavily depend on relatability to some degree or another; if you don't empathize with at least one or some of the characters and the situations they're in, you will despise each and every one of them for being ridiculous in the way they approach practically everything.


However, I would contend that from an empathetic point of view, each main character in Scum's wish is beautifully crafted and written. Each occupy different enough aspects of the phenomenon known as 'love' that likely someone could relate to at least one of the characters, and perhaps acknowledge the pain of a few others. 


I don't think its really fair to write off a character you don't necessarily like in Scum as just that, Scum. Or more importantly, Scum that deserve nothing. Whilst each character gets some form of 'redemption' by the end of the series, they're all motivated to do what they do throughout the series by very human emotions. Love, jealousy, hate, desire, loneliness, wanting. They're not glamorous emotions, certainly not portrayed as such in Scum's wish, but nobody's going to be perfect, at least not in Scum's Wish. 


The characters all pursue their own goals for themselves, no matter how much they may be hurting themselves or others in the long run. If you watch Scum's Wish, you shouldn't be expecting a nice and happy turnaround in the likes of Toradora or other rom-coms that leave your heart aflutter with mushy pink-tinged joy. I'm not disparaging those shows or those that like them, I'm part of that crowd myself, but Scum's Wish's characters cut so deeply to the core that I'm obliged to regard them as some of the most 'realistic' in a lot of senses. Hence the perfect score.



Enjoyment: 10/10



Just a short note here, but as I've stated numerous times in this review; Scum's Wish heavily depends on the relatability that the viewer has towards any one of the characters. If you relate to none of them, you may find the show very difficult to take seriously as anything other than a depression circle-jerk. If you relate to one of them, you may find yourself going "God no, I don't need these memories. But it's done so well." Or you may be in the unenviable position like I am, of being able to relate to multiple characters. Hence, I 'enjoyed' the show to the fullest. 10/10 barely accounts for how much I deeply connect with the show. My liver may not be thanking me for the amount of times I've painfully had to indulge in alcohol to numb the pain of bad memories brought up by this show, but no other show has done that so I'm willing to give Scum's Wish significant sway in that regard. 



Summary/Overall: 9/10



I've probably made clear why I think Scum's Wish deserves a far better reputation and review score than I've seen it get. Again, the only real thing preventing me from giving this a full 10/10 is the fact that it relies so heavily on the characters and their situations being relatable for a viewer to empathize. Do I think that should cause my rating to be dropped more because of it? Not at all. People have genres or themes that they will not watch because they can't get invested enough in it or simply don't find it 'interesting', and I think this applies to Scum's Wish. Someone may quickly find it unenjoyable, but someone else who can relate may find it immediately intriguing. I do not think a show should simply be written off because you may not be able to 'understand' the motivations of a character or characters. 


I'll reiterate, Scum's Wish is painful. It's a show that dredges up pretty much all the negative aspects of love, and all its undoings. But it does have a positive resolution. One that makes sense, and is a testament to how far the characters have come from their initial entry. I jokingly mentioned to some friends that Scum's Wish would end in a murder suicide because one of the characters couldn't take the frustrations and anger of their situation any more. I'm genuinely glad that the series resolved as it did, in quite a mature way considering how the first half dozen episodes went, and I would summarily consider it one of the greatest shows dealing with a 'real' sense of love, that is, one that isn't completely blotted out with rose-tint and deals heavily with the times that we, as people, feel shitty, lonely, and terrible about ourselves.


Scum may be scum, but they also have wishes too. And if they're capable of superseding that, who are we to judge if we cannot say the same?

~Intro
Scum's Wish is a series not everybody will enjoy. The drama present in this anime deosn't appeal to everyone, alot of watchers will be mad and frustrated with the characters and their actions, but others will probably find a liking to it. I personally really loved this show and now I'm going to tell you why.
~Story
The story of Scum's Wish is dark. It's filled with unrequited crushes, lonelyness, pain and other things of this sort. It shows us the dark side of love, but also gives us some comedy here and there. The pacing is good and the anime stayed close to the original manga.It also isn't afraid to show some expilcit scenes, which had a purpose and weren't bothering me atleast. I overall really liked the story ^^.


~Art

Art and animation are really pretty and look great. I also really like the use of paneling in this show. It makes it stand out and is a really unique way, that haven't seen explored in other shows that much. Even though i have to admit, that i like the manga-artstyle a little more, they tried capturing the original style as much as possible.


~Sound

I really liked the OST and after the show finished airing I listened to it multiple times and fell in love with alot of the tracks (for example the one from ep. 11).


~Characters

All of them have some sorts of unrequited and dark feelings in them (exept one or two), this allone makes them in many ways relateable. None of them are really good and nice people, but this makes them good written characters in a sense. All of them (exept one or two) go trough a developement and at the end of the series all of them (exept one or two) learn from their experience and grow because of it. The character designs are also really pretty, simple and good on the eye. (And Hanabi is super pretty. So pretty, that i already drew her alot lol)


~Enjoyment

I had a lot of fun watching this anime. There were times were i enjoyed the show more than at over times, but was it a really good experience nonetheless.


~Overall

As already said, this anime might not appeal to everyone and i already heard people say, that it was too much drama for them, but I really liked Scum's Wish. It is a show, that i won't forget that easily.

I give it a solid 9/10. I really loved this show and I can recommend it to some, but not to everyone.

What if i told you there was a softcore porn anime with the inanity of School Days and all the "artsy" pompousness of Shigatsu?  If you have a modicum of taste, you may look at me in disbelief, wondering why anybody would birth that kind of abomination.  Yet here we are, Kuzu no Honkai is very much real, and every bit as dreadful as you can imagine.  But miraculously, KNH is entertaining, precisely because it is bad.  
The concept is simple : we have here a cast of characters who do nothing but have sex with each other in random andever changing permutations.  The catch is that none of them enjoy having sex or even yearn for it.  No, they just do it because the authors decided that it would have some sort of "deep", life-changing significance.  While it may fly for the 13 year old female viewers, those of us who are older and more jaded will realize it to be the pinnacle of pretentious stupidity.  And that's the story.  No really, that's it.  There is no real conflict, no accomplishment, and no progression.  Just a bunch of idiots having sex and getting petty and jealous for nearly 5 hours. 


Up to now it must still sound pretty awful and you must wonder how i could find any entertainment in this.  The key lies in the execution.  I'm not exaggerating at all when i say that 75% of the show is characters having inner, sappy, whispery monologues.   It's so annoying and bad, that i couldn't actually get annoyed by it.  Rather, i was amazed and bewildered, wondering how low it could get.  I was on the edge of my seat with a chronometer, seeing what is the longest shitty monologue, seeing if it would set a new record.  It's a bit like Poe's law.  But here it's somehow more organic than a pure parody, because it wasn't intended to be.  It's just one because i decided it to be, as the viewer.  


Part of these monologues are what i call epiphanies.  You know, when character A says something really inane, but the writers decided that it would instead be a "deep" statement, then character B launches on a 5 minute tirade about how he finally realized "something".  Every character has at least 10 of these throughout the series, since they spend most of their time introspecting about themselves.  And it became a game for me to try to anticipate when would be the next epiphany, or to count how many they could cram in a single episode.  


Oh yeah, the characters.  In all likelihood, you will hate every single one of them.  I mean, what is more annoying than teenagers who do nothing but internally whine about their free-of-real-conflict lives?  But here the despicable characters are an asset.  I don't know about you, but i enjoy seeing people i hate suffer, and KNH really delivers that type of satisfaction.  Don't expect true pain though, just woe-is-me depression over yesterday's "life-altering" sexual encounter.  But it was enough for me, if i couldn't enjoy their sadness, i could at least laugh at them.  


But really the show's strongest point are the pretentious little artsy devices that are densely sprinkled throughout.  You know, like when a tear falls from a character's face and falls into an abstract background and creates water ripples.  Or when the screen cuts out to a black background with some very "deep" 2 words in the middle that some character then says after a long pause, with all the dramatic intent he can muster.  You know what i mean.  These were profoundly hilarious to me.  Just one cliche after another, and there is so many of them that it just adds to the humor.  


Another source of entertainment is the visuals.  The art is very good, with lots of details.  Eyelashes are meticulously drawn, not just a thick black line.  The hair actually looks like hair and not just a piece of hard, colored plastic.  At the beginning, there are also some top notch lewd scenes.  This isn't your 100$ budget hentai, and one of your only chances at seeing a properly detailed and animated kiss in an anime.  Unfortunately, as usually happens, they concentrate the explicit stuff in the first 1-2 episodes to reel you in, then barely include any in the later parts of the show.  


So to summarize, KNH is a true gem in the "good because it's bad" category.  The problem is that it gets old pretty quickly, due to, well, nothing happening or changing.  The lewdness tapering off also contributed to make this a test of patience to get to the end.  If you are able to put yourself on 3-4 layers of irony, i would recommend watching the first 2-3 episodes, and stopping there.  You will have seen all there is to see.

Not a lot of anime this season have tried a somewhat realistic approach to deliver its story. Kuzu no Honkai is no exception. It was uncomfortable to watch, really, but this factor subsided quickly. I, for one, skipped most of the scenes because they've lost their reason to even be shown. To be able to convey everything I mean with the least spoilers, I'll break the review down to 4 parts: the beginning, climax, end, and my overview of the series along with the characters.
Starting from the beginning, the facial expressions really did add a lot to keep me entertained, especially giving viewers a quickbut not clear view of the problem our characters will face. Since the first few episodes are the most critical ones, Kuzu no Honkai executed things perfectly to show viewers what's wrong without letting it decay in such an early point.


At its peak, it somewhat felt lacking. Of course this isn't a review without anything bad said about it. In a show where sentiments basically kept it moving, I wondered where all of those went. During its final episodes, we see the show move on two different paths, not coinciding with each other. We see Hanabi's and Mugi's time alone in one episode but I wonder, where would the climax be? Could it be with Akane? Or with Sanae? You see, you can split a show in two but somehow, to achieve a peak, you have to tie them together. The climax is the quintessential part of a show, but would it be up to the viewers to decide where and who's path it would be? The problem here is that their actions don't affect the other. [SPOILERS] Hanabi's confession to Narumi did nothing to change anything about Akane's night with Mugi. And I'm not blaming the show for that, it's just that it was written in a way that didn't really matter to the other. And even so, where did Mugi's "know-it-all" senses go? I thought they agreed to get rejected? In my view, their failed confessions could've been a good peak, but somehow, the character development went one-sided.


Now for the end, I would say, it's painful to watch, but it's the best for them both. The decision to go for a neutral route and not ride onto the momentum of [SPOILER] Narumi and Akane's engagement was not just a great idea but also a great closure. This also keeps the show bound to realism. Remember that even though they wanted to start an actual relationship after getting rejected, Mugi's disobedience to their agreement showed that their decisions were rather forced, or was meant to fill the hole that's about to be made from their rejections. In a deeper understanding, they knew that trying to be an actual couple would actually just be doing what they've done in the start of show: to be a replacement for the people they can't have. So that's why searching for "true love" was the best ending for them both and I couldn't've wanted it any other way.


As an overview of this sad, twisted tale of star-crossed lovers, I would say, it couldn't've been done any better (except for the inclusion of a peak). The frustration, deception, and feeling of being lost were accurate enough to be considered realism instead of the cliche this show's filled of. Kuzu no Honkai isn't a series where you'll see a lot of laughs, or high-schoolers acting stupidly. This show is as serious as it gets. It bathes in sadness so much that you develop empathy even for the characters that's barely looked at. The show explores metaphorical loss but can be felt just as "emptening" as "Clannad", "AnoHana", and other heavy drama shows.


On a final note, I can only hope to see more shows such as Kuzu no Honkai. Nowadays, those shows are a rare find as most studios focus on Action or Fantasy genres that you really can't see a "down-to-earth" show anywhere this season.


With that said, hats off to Kuzu no Honkai. You've almost accurately portrayed the feelings and emotions etched with "young love" that a lot of people only despise as shallow and turbulent thoughts. This, is realism. And this is how failed romances should be.

Short as it is, the introduction of Kuzu no Honkai. It begins with the unrequited love and desire to be with someone that they can't have. It leads them to form a promise together as lover. By doing so, they can embrace each other as they imagine it's the person they love. Both are falling for the teachers in their school. Mugi loves Akane-sensei who exhibits the elegance (and quite his type). Hana loves Kanai-sensei who's so dear with her since she was a child. Of course, those problematic feelings are intercalated by other characters feelings (love) too. They are ironicallytrapped in scum's wish to be with the one that they can't be with...



STORY - CHARARACTERIZATION

    I'm not an enthusiast in drama & romance. In fact, I'm very selective when I do watch the genres. I picked this, put it into my must-watch list right after finishing the 1st ep. "This anime is really heavy," what was I thought. From the intro in the 1st ep, it is very clear all ep won't be full of affection. It's indeed the story that will rip the smile apart (moreover if you like to pair one with each other, be prepared).

     The timing they use to bring things up is perfect. Like when the teacher meets with the main characters unexpectedly, the confession of Hanabi's friend, the yelling of Moka, accidental meeting with minor characters and many more. It goes smooth yet, once again, heavy. The story tries to make us understood how having such a dear feeling like love can be ​mentally sickening, reeling. It makes us think which side is right or wrong, what is more appropriate to do. Everyone here has their own basic reasoning in which supporting every deeds they do, nobody is wrong. They have different fears and kind of emotions to face, but it's all categorized the same "to someone they love". Weak mental stability can easily get stabbed every time the soliloquies appear, it's pretty distressing yet beautifully described.

     Those characters. both in major and minor characters categories, are round type. All of them change along the story progress. It's shown by how mentally wounded their soul in soliloquies and therefore it changes themselves, like their thoughts, opinions, perspective, decisions, not to mention, feelings. Their characters development is progressive, as well as the characterization from other characters to each other in the meantime. The characters development shows the beginning 'til the end of the time they face their own problems and priority to what path they are going to choose and do.

​


VISUALIZATION

     The visualization sync perfectly notable when it's the soliloquies when flow of the words describing the feeling and nuance really makes sense. It's logic from mind and it's understandable from heart. The words or thoughts itself are painful, killing. Almost every time the soliloquies fade away, it jumps to another scene or back to reality, the closure feels like we're drawn to sink with its somber ideas. The close-up characters faces are good, the male characters are plenty while parts of female characters face are graceful. Well, about the ecchi scenes itself, which are more than just enough ('till its get denouncement for its sexual content), is notable. It's great from the visualization and story. It's not in a rush to engage in intimate doing, slowly and in a logical way with clear reason why it puts there. I don't think there's no harm from this series from the beginning because it's already claimed that the genres would be ecchi and seinen too. I thought everyone should pay attention more to it and increase the awareness of it. Well, whatever tho' XD The surrounding visualization is ornamented well, soft yet resolute colouring with subtle contour. The slow motion is the best when they're getting contradiction within themselves.



MUSIC

      The meaningful lyrics from the theme songs are killing, it always burns up the feelings there and make it heavier. It can make you cry if you really into the story (or at least quite sensitive). ​The insert songs (instruments) really play along, support well the tension when Hanabi and other characters are feeling themselves in The edge of frustration. The OP is sung by 96neko, one of my favorite because of her lower voice yet firm, "Uso no Hibana (嘘の火花)". It's worth to say it's one of the best theme songs in WINTER 2017 season. Then, we have the ED by Sayuri "Heikousen (平行線)". As the OP, it also has meaningful theme songs. Makes us feel that the characters can have everything but their feelings, like they signed the pact to make the person s/he likes happy, but wanted themselves to be saved pathetically.



     Kuzu no Honkai brings sudden revolution to drama & romance genres, even with R+ (mild nudity) scenes. It opens the possibility to understand more the basic reasoning of someone's doing regardless of how slut or weak s/he is in the name of love. The scums' wishes dreadfully about love and people existence, it rocks 9++!

Why can love make you feel so lonely?
Hanabi and Mugi are a “fake" high school couple. They are both in love with teachers at their school. It’s not just a naive “I love the teacher” romance, but something far more interesting. Hanabi has a crush on her childhood friend who is now her homeroom teacher. But, he only sees her as the little girl whom he took care of like a sister. Mugi fell in love with his former tutor, currently a music teacher. However, she pretends to not notice his stares and glances. Brought together by their mutual loneliness, Hanabi and Mugi are justusing each other as substitutes for their true feelings. It sounds like awful relationship, but for them it’s much better than being alone.


If that sounds depressing, that’s not all there is to it. They aren’t lucky enough to live out their faux romance in peace. In their minds, they constantly agonize over their feelings and question if this is what they really want. Then at every turn, someone else wants to take over their already warped and distorted love lives. The people around them seem single-mindedly tunnel-visioned on their own ideal of love - willing to hurt others and sadly even themselves to get what they believe would make them happy.


This is a story filled to the brim with the dirty and smutty side of love. Unrequited love. Forbidden love. Love as a form of abusable power over others. It’s safe to say this isn't a show for the average anime viewer. Instead of a normal plot of building up drama and suspense to get a payoff of warm, happy feelings at the end. We have a love story that repeatedly makes you feel worse - to the point that you as the viewer might feel abused. Characters do awful things that are meant to make you feel a mix of disgust and pity. Drama in the story develops like a slow throbbing pain with twists and turns stemming from selfishness and lust. You constantly fear everything will keep getting worse. To use the blanket term "love story" would be a bit disingenuous.


But for that reason, I believe Kuzu no Honkai is something special. If I didn’t scare you away by telling you what the story is about, then you’re in for a gorgeous anime. Everything from beautiful animation to distinctively crisp voice acting to scene directing makes it a great example of anime done right. The artistic style and character design were great but the sound editing and voice acting absolutely stood out of the most. What feels like half the show is done in internal thoughts and monologues, which really allows for the voice acting to shine. The characters seem like they are speaking directly into your ears. Directing for the animation is done with a clearly artistic direction to carry the concept as far as possible. Psychological and emotional scenarios are brought to life with gorgeous art and visual effects. Intimate scenes are crafted so well that you can’t help but feel a bit awkward for prying into someone else’s life.


I really can’t stop praising how well this anime handled such an ugly topic. For what it sets out to do, Kuzu no Honkai does an amazing job. It almost too ambitiously tackles all the ugly parts of romance. And it doesn’t baby us with the naive approach of telling us how to deal with all of these problems - there’s no pretending that they have the answers and no goal to make us feel good. As a viewer, don't take this show at face value - especially in real life, there isn't always a clear resolution. Love can make you feel terrible, but it’s ultimately just part of regular human life.


For anyone who wants to watch an anime that breaks the traditional romance mold in order to reach something more genuine, watch this anime.


As a side note, even though the characters weren’t designed to be adored, I think Hanabi is just too precious for this world.

6.5/10. A masterpiece of a first half let down by an absolutely atrocious final third. [REVIEW CONTAINS HEAVY SPOILERS]
I'll get why I loved the show in the first part out of the way. Kuzu no Honkai is to the teenage romance triangle genre what School Days was to the harem genre. While most other shows take a real life scenario to its most fantastical extreme, Kuzu no Honkai goes the complete opposite direction and takes it to its most logical extreme. I feel that my enjoyment of it is more due to the sad state of the industry rather than anything it did exceptionally well.It's main drawing point is that it is a rather realistic romance show, in an industry where romance is portrayed as anything but realistic.


While most romance series go through its entire run without the characters ever confessing their feelings for each other, or if we are lucky, a kiss in the final episode, Kuzu no Honkai goes straight off the bat in the first episode to the characters making out with each other. In that sense, the potential for development in this series is already in an entire league than the conventional romance anime. Not to mention that saying that the show is a love triangle is a complete understatement. In fact, it is more of a love octogon. Everybody is in some sort of twisted relationship with a multitude of other characters. Of course, there are far worst scenarios in hentai, but in that case I view the characters as just fap material for someone’s weird fetish. In this case, I approach anime seriously and view these characters as very real human beings with real personalities. Unless you are the type that is unable to separate porn from other forms of visual entertainment, it is impossible not to feel for the characters.


I felt the a sense of unbearable nausea when watching the show, something akin to the feeling I had when watching Aku no Hana or Shinsekai Yori. It is so much till the extent that when I watch the sex scenes, I don’t feel turned on, but rather I am on the verge of crying and screaming at the screen for the characters to please just fucking stop. It was so emotionally exhausting to watch. I had originally intended to marathon the whole series in one or two days, but it was simply too depressing and painful that I couldn’t watch more than one or two episodes in a day without needing to take a break to recover some of my emotional sanity. I spend hours upon hours after each episode ended thinking of each of the character’s emotional state and motivations. The show succeeded brilliantly in this regard. Coupled with the phenomenal OP and ED, I truly felt that Kuzu no Honkai had the potential to be one of the most revolutionary genre-defining shows of the decade.


I have to question how much of “true love” Hanabi’s feelings for Kanai, and Mugi’s feelings for Akane were. To the show’s credit, they never force a definite viewpoint on the audience, and mainly just show the relationships through Hanabi’s and Mugi’s perception, leaving the viewers to make up their own minds about it.


Since Hanabi has known Kanai from way back in her childhood, even before she had any sexual awareness, it is much easier to view her feelings as genuine. Yet, there is the sense that Kanai is just her idealization of the absent father figure in her life, which is poignant irony given that the entire reason why Kanai chooses Akane over Hanabi in the end is arguably because of his Oedipus complex (more on that later). Also, as much as I try to put myself in her shoes, there is no way that closing her eyes while making out with Mugi and imagining that Mugi is Kanai is an accurate reflection of “true love”. That is the very epitome of sexual desire. It would be interesting to have an analysis from a female viewer’s point of view about it.


If anything, I’m a male, so I should be sympathetic of the male characters and spiteful of the female characters, but in fact I find it the other way around. While I can see why a lot of people would hate Akane, honestly it’s not as if she forced anybody to have sex with her at gunpoint. Everybody willingly fucked with her completely of their own accord and their own sexual desire. You could say that she “used” them, but everybody knew they were being used and still chose to go along with it.


I can give the females some benefit of the doubt, but I'm a guy and I know when Mugi is completely talking out of his ass. Bottom line is, he puts his sexual desire first and foremost. Which is nothing wrong, and you can put on a facade for the other characters as much as you want, but it's utterly disgusting how he even lies to himself in his internal monologues. At least Hanabi openly admits that she cannot tell the difference between love and lust anymore. Akane, while easily being the most morally empty character, has never pretended from the start that she was anything more than a slut that uses men. We never have any sort of moment like this from Mugi. Regarding Mugi’s feelings for Akane, I have no doubt in my mind that it was almost completely sexual attraction. Their only previous interactions are that of student and tutor, and coming from someone that has gone through a lot of tuition classes in my life, I simply do not see how any kind of meaningful interaction can comes about from that. Just look at how many times Mugi had sex with Akane before even thinking to go on a date with her. And this is his behaviour towards a person he claims he has “true love” for. How much worst would his behaviour be towards a female he views only as a sex object? To see Mugi trying to explain away his sexual desires for Akane to himself as some kind of true love is particularly revolting, and it really makes me question how much of his internal psyche is reliable as a narrator. If he lies to himself about Akane, then how can the audience trust his internal monologues regarding Hanabi or Moka?


I genuinely felt that Hanabi, while being addicted to sexual pleasure and massively confused regarding the boundaries between love and lust, was undeniably yearning for something more in her relationship with Mugi. Mugi on the other hand, had a dick in place of brains. He’s not content with just fucking Hanabi, also goes out of his way to call his childhood friend to fuck and takes advantage of Moka’s infatuation with him to make out with her. Again, sexual desire is a perfectly normal thing for a human being, but what repulses me is Mugi’s complete pretentiousness about it.


The series arguably reached its high point midway through when Hanabi effectively becomes no different from Akane, trying to possess everyone who desires Akane. That is a very interesting direction I would loved the show to have taken. That everyone has the potential to become complete scum if pushed far enough. It would have been beautiful; a girl who has her “true love” taken away by a conniving slut incapable of love, eventually transforms into the very being which she hates, becoming yet another conniving slut incapable of love, and the whole cycle repeats once again.


However, the last third is when all previously established characterization flies out of the window. There was a huge tonal shift from that moment onwards and the whole show went downhill till the point that I couldn’t even believe it was the same series I was watching before.


There was the extremely odd decision to suddenly ditch Hanabi as the main character and put the focus on Akane. If the ultimate aim of the series was to showcase some kind of transformation from the previously unredeemable Akane, then make her the main character in the first place! Maybe then they could have crafted enough justification for the viewers to swallow her so-called “transformation”. Why do you spend 8 whole episodes developing Hanabi and Mugi’s relationship only to shaft it to the side and focus on something else for the remaining 4 episodes?


So Akane, who has spent her whole life sleeping with countless men and using them for her own amusement, suddenly falls in love with Kanai because he does not mind being cucked? WTF? I think this could have been a really poignant development if only they took the time to really develop it, say gradually over the course of the entire series. Instead, we get a whole lifetime of characterisation undone in the space of a single episode. Hey, the power of love trumps all yeah? Completely out of left field.


Kanai is one of the biggest cucks I've ever seen in any medium. So he is fine with marrying Akane despite her, in her exact own words, being a slut and fine with her sleeping with other men despite their relationship? This works if he is in it just for the sex, but since the show chooses not to portray his motivations that way, then what is it? The show tries to portray his love as some kind of “selfless unconditional love”, but is it really like that? If he was even in love with her personality in the first place, then why would he still be in love with her given that her façade has been exposed to be nothing but a fraud? And if he’s not in it for the sexual aspect, what is he in it for? Why does he love Akane? The answer is then obviously because she is nothing but an idealization in his eyes.


This brings about the disturbing implication is that Kanai is in love with Akane solely because she resembles his dead mother. Being “in love” for the sole sake of sexual gratification is tragic and all, but because of his Oedipus complex? Fucking hell. The fact that their relationship was the only one that, at least of a surface level, worked out in the end out of the many others that failed in the series is particularly horrific. Out of all the relationships in the show, this is ultimately the most hollow and superficial one. If the show could spend a ridiculous amount of screentime on the shallow Mugi, who’s entire psyche can be summed up in three words “I was horny”, then why does it neglect the most important motivation begging to be explored; that of Kanai and his Oedipus complex? I think instead of casting their relationship as “the power of true love”, it would be much more effective if the series had explored this particular disturbing aspect, that ultimately the only successful relationship in the whole show is the biggest sham of all.


Hanabi’s “development” from sleeping around unable to control her sexual urges to suddenly deciding to wait for true love is again completely out of left field. If anything, I thought her rejection by Kanai, coupled together with Mugi sleeping together with Akane, would completely drive her off the deep end. She was already sleeping around with multiple people, why does she decide to stop all of a sudden? There is no logical explanation for this. So when the possibility of a relationship with Kanai still exists, she sleeps around with Mugi, with her lesbian friend, with some random guy she bumps into at the train station, but the moment Kanai has concretely rejected her, she stops doing so anymore? Why? The entire point of her sexual relationships in the first place was to try and fill a void that was left in her by Kanai. The void is still there. For a character that was crying and one step away from a complete emotional breakdown every single episode at the start, it is unnatural how she reverts back to relative normalcy in the closing episodes for no particular reason at all. Character’s emotional states aren’t something for the writers to conveniently use and change at the flick of a switch if the plot so happens to call for it. Emotional hurt is something long lasting and if there is a change in the psyche of a character, there better damn well be a good explanation for it, something this show completely fails to provide.


Ecchan’s willingness to let go of Hanabi was a complete farce too. So when Hanabi was still in a relationship with Mugi, and still had the possibility of being accepted by Kanai, Ecchan had no problem with having sex with her (even touching her while in the school library for fuck’s sake) and openly telling Mugi’s about Hanabi’s infidelity in a fit of possessiveness. But now that Hanabi has been rejected by Kanai, and is no longer seeing Mugi, Ecchan suddenly decides that she is not going to have sexual relations with Hanabi anymore? Utterly ridiculous. If anything, Ecchan’s relationship with Hanabi was easily the most toxic and possessive of all, so for her to give it up with absolutely zero justification is all the more confusing.


There is nothing that the show to warrant the characters to make such changes. The show has the audacity to attempt to fool the viewers that these characters had developed in some way, namely that they were able to overcome their sexual desires in the pursuit of true love. Rubbish. In the final episode, if Mugi had tried to kiss Hanabi, or vice versa, or if Ecchan had tried to kiss Hanabi, or vice versa, it would have delved into a full blown make-out session, as has been the case throughout the entire series. It’s fine not to have development over the course of a series, real life is like that, people don’t change sometimes. But what I hate the most the forced fake development that is thrown in for the sake of it just because it is the finale.


The writers use multiple time skips covering entire months within the space of the final episode in an attempt to sell this “development” but it comes across as entirely artificial and contrived. Most series use time skips very carefully and at most once or twice during the entire course of the show. To have it multiple times in just one episode reeks of lazy writing, where they realize that they cannot possibly organically justify the characters’ transformations, and thus just fast forward the show in a farcical attempt at development.


Another criticism I have for the series is that the writers takes the easy way out; rather than show that all characters are equally detestable, they very conveniently use the sociopathic Akane in order to get the viewers to feel some kind of sympathy to Hanabi and Mugi. Objectively, Hanabi and Mugi are both characters that are rotten to the core, but the writers try to paint them as some kind of sympathetic heroine/hero because there's a character with an even more deplorable moral compass. Akane becomes a scapegoat the viewers can blame all the emotional turmoil the other characters are experiencing on.


This is especially the case in how the show tries to portray Hanabi as some sort of victimised tragic character. She willingly sleeps with multiple people, but hey, she's still "pure" because she never went all the way with them. Oh come on. She’s as filthy as all the other characters in the show. It is true that Ecchan’s desire for Hanabi was bordering on forceful and rapey, but if Hanabi truly did not want to have sexual relations with her, she could simply have walked away. She gave in to her lust all the same despite feeling it was wrong. Frankly, there’s nothing that the characters in the show does that I, or the majority of human being in their position would not do, but that’s the whole point. Humans will hurt others and trample over others in order to fulfil their own selfish desires. Yes, Hanabi is indeed the victim, but at the same time she is also the aggressor, she also manipulates and toys with others, and it is important to keep that in mind while feeling sorry for her.


Additionally, the series is terrible in the sense that internal monologues plague every single episode. Have the writers ever heard of "show, not tell"? The writers’ idea of characterization is literally having whole minutes on characters babbling on inside their heads. It’s flogging a dead horse. Why even bother to have proper characterization when you can just have some psycho-babble, right? And it’s not like the show is trying to tell its viewers: "hey, look at these pretentious fucks trying to rationalize their desire for sexual pleasure as something deeper", the show tries to pass of these internal monologues are something legit. It’s almost like the show is trying to scream: "Look how deep I am! Look at my internal anguish and conflict!" and beat the viewers over the head with it.


I have seen people praising the ending as realistic. Were they even watching the same show as I was? Which particular relationship is realistically resolved? They point to the fact that Hanabi and Mugi don’t end up together as some kind of proof that the show had such a “deep” “bittersweet” ending. People praising the ending claim that they avoided the typical happy ending of romance anime. But if you ask me, the ending completely at odds with the tone and characterisation and themes brought up over the course of the series. Yes, it’s a bittersweet ending if you compare with the endings of most other series, but comparing the series with itself, with the tone and emotional turmoil set in the first half, the ending is an unnaturally optimistic one.


The people that want to see Mugi and Hanabi together don’t actually mean that they love each other. Well, I won’t deny that there are some people that want some lovey-dovey ending with Hanabi and Mugi finding “true love” with each other, but those kind of people have missed the entire point of the show in the first place. The show has made it clear that frankly Mugi never saw Hanabi as anything but a sex object. Vice versa, I’ll give Hanabi the benefit of the doubt, but it is undeniable that the vast majority of their so-called relationship was nothing but sexual pleasure.


What I mean, and what I think a lot of other people mean when they say they want an ending with Mugi and Hanabi together is both of them being in a sham relationship, using each other for sexual pleasure and deluding themselves that they have feelings for each other. Which is effectively no different from the start. And that’s the whole point. An utterly depressing ending, with each of the two leads making absolutely zero progress in finding true love, and in fact being even further away from it than ever because Kanai and Akane are married. For a show whose entire premise in the first place was to take the genre of teenage romance to its logical extreme, why doesn’t it choose to go all the way? Why stop short?


The whole show was building up to a tipping point, but when the point came, there was no spectacular collapse, it just kind of fizzled out. They spent 8 whole episodes tearing down the characters only for it to amount to nothing in the end. What exactly are the consequences for the malicious hurtful actions all of the characters have inflicted on others and have been inflicted on themselves throughout the series? Nothing much to be honest.


The show’s entire selling point was that it is not like all the other cliché romance dramas, only to turn that on its head in the end, which is utterly disappointing. The series, which had initially prided itself on its realism, becomes an exercise in suspension of disbelief. It wants to do a different take on the romance genre, but instead of seeing it through to its logical extreme, does a complete 360. Instead of maintaining its direction all the way to the bitter ending, Kuzu no Honkai decides to pussy out and incorporate elements of a typical cliché romance. And we’re left wondering what could have been. Nonetheless, the phenomenal set-up in the first half and it’s refreshing take on the teenage romance genre makes this a must-watch. It’s such a pity the show did not have the vision and ambition to follow it through to the end.

"SPOILER WARNING" 
Kuzu no Honkai introduces itself as a rebellious new style of storytelling,       going against the norm of society and giving an insight into the "unspoken" parts of relationships, which many will often keep to themselves or behind closed doors. It is this in-depth portrayal of the lewd and scandalous that gains the show traction and has it being discussed constantly.
Story: 8/10
The plot and its decision to focus in on the more physical aspects of the relationship is a double-edged sword. This risquéness and the uncomfortable atmosphere it creates is the basis of why the show has receivedso much traction.  The energy that the show gained from its racy scenes carried the anime in its earlier episodes. The downside of this is that the show relied far too heavily on the physical, and its effect wore off by episode 4-5. This is partially why some of the relationships seemed to lack any emotional foundations as the show focused in on more of the physical aspects. (by these relationships I am referencing to those involving Sanae and Noriko) When their relationships wore down and broke apart, the show neglected to highlight the emotional turmoil and after effects which followed, almost as if the story didn't affect the main characters as a person and how they thought or viewed the world.

An exception to this where the show focused in on the emotional consequences very well was with Akane and Narumi in the last few episodes, where the relationship developed who they were, and also showed how the relationship was changing them mentally as a person.



Art: 7/10

By "art"  I will also focus in on cinematography and visual effects. The art style and colour grade share resemblances to a palette of watercolors, which was a smart decision. The saturated and pale colours suit the somber and often depressing mood of the show well. The "comic strip" style of transitioning was also a nice touch, adding some energy in between the shots and an effective way of showing flashbacks and memories to the audience.



Sound: 8/10

The opening "Uso no Hibana" by 96neko was a good song choice. Personally, it didn't fit the mood of the show as effectively as the ending, however it mare no noticeable difference to the enjoyment of the show. The ending song, "Heikousen" by Sayuri was an amazing pick and honestly my favourite ending of this season, the atmosphere it created couldn't have fit the show any better, and the slow transition into the ending song was really effective at emphasizing the last few words said in each episode and carrying along the message. The soundtrack, composed by Masaru Yokoyama, who also composed great pieces for other anime such as Your Lie in April, created a smooth-flowing score which suited the atmosphere and specific shots well. Although no specific piece stands out above the others, the score is still well-rounded and delivers where necessary.



Characters: 7/10 

Overall most of the character don't fit into any stereotype or abide by the standard anime tropes, they are all interesting individuals to a certain extent nad all undergo reasonable development, thanks to monologuing and backstories. Hanabi's original portrayal as sweet and innocent is turned on its head after her relationship with Mugi, as she doesn't know how to react or feel anymore. The scenes of Hanabi debating with herself, although few in number, gave a good insight into her inner thoughts, especially when dealing with Narumi, and gave a fresh contrast to the typical monologue. One thing, however, which the anime failed in doing was getting the viewer attached to the characters, especially when it came to the characters of Noriko nad Sanae, who received little development, and so their relationships had little effect on the main characters. The ending of the relationship between Mugi and Akane also lacked any emotional backing, largely due to the lack of development we received for Mugi.

The character of Noriko tended to annoy me at times, who often bordered on the tsundere loli trope, and was generally underdeveloped and had little driving force behind her feelings other than childhood fantasies.


Enjoyment: 8/10

I'm a cynical cold bastard who's favourite animes include most tragic romances, and who's preferred genres are anything that will bring me remotely close to feeling. It was unlikely that I would not enjoy the show. Although this does mean that my review would likely be slightly biased, I atempted to keep it rounded as much as possible.


Overall, Kuzu no Honkai did not fail to impress with its drastic contrast to the typical outlook on most relationships found in anime, and regardless of you preferred genre or type of show, this anime offers a unique view into character development, relationships, and the romance genre as a whole, which I believe everyone should experience .

Kuzu no Honkai is one of those animes which just burst into my life like waking up one morning to a broad white field of snow that covered everything around me. It's just this anime which takes you deep into how the author wants to make you feel about it. The creator hasn't done this artwork to please the maximum of people. Just like going out of your home into a blizzard, stunned in wonder and beauty, or in shivers and frost, or if you are me: in both. I take that the author followed his own instincts, this is what makes this piece veryconfronting, and I especially like that about it. You will understand better why I say all of this when you read my review as a whole.


Story 10/10

This story is just so full of surprises. In every episode we discover something new, and in a very, very dramatic way. The way ideas are presented to us is simply bold and strongly linked to each characters deeper inner voice. The story builds on in the few first episodes with a suspenseful tranquility, to then make its rise into emotion with even more ferocity by having huge contrasts between episodes which all have their own turn and feel. The episodes seem to appear in a fashion of mini movies in the way that they come out as being very clear in their development within the story and in how much mind-challenge each one holds. I was personally really moved by the ideas that were suggested in Kuzu no Honkai, not only because of how novel they were to me, but especially because of the way in which they struck me.


Art 10/10

The art is simply bliss. Each scenery just flows into the other without any struggle whatsoever. You just get trapped into the story. I really like it when this anime sometimes looms manga-like images into the video, it makes it even more authentic and inclines me to be more involved with such an art piece. The artwork on characters is just magnificent, it's an art so beautiful and yet very distinct to itself. I'm really into a manga/anime when the art is beautiful. I suppose it makes me feel like the thing is more real because my feelings cling easier to the beauty of characters, and in turn more importantly to their personality which may then make my experience even more emotionally tangible. What I especially liked was how the art worked subtly with sounds by combining with purpose, like a triggering tempo.


Sound 10/10

It speaks to me a whole lot on this level. The music and sound in this anime is incredible. I know I often introduce an idea by only giving adjectives, but the thing is I don't use words when I don't think them with real honesty and without keeping up my stance up to them. The character's voice choice is a pure delight. They represent the characters as in who they are with precision. The surrounding sounds make the experience more palpable. We can really feel how the creators choose carefully each and every sound that is being realized. The music in itself eludes so much into the art piece by allowing to flow at the right time, and by having been composed with intent. The smallest sounds really freak me out though, a finger touching wood, the kissing, the whispers, the flow of wind, the emotional tone...


Characters 10/10

Characters simply go beyond my own expectations. They are full of intrigue, even the one's that first appear as being really bland and dull, develop into their very own piece's of work. The way in which we are projected into their lifes ; an inception that works out emotions of your own as a release into the more concrete. I personally got caught up so tight with Noriko's impression of the world. The way in which the episode focused on her is brought into life is simply amazing.


Enjoyment 10/10

I can simply not express my enjoyment enough with such a short and simple review. I thought at the least, that I should give back the people who made this anime some of my gratitude. This is only the second review I have written so far on my anime list, and I won't write one unless tremendously moved.


Overall 10/10

I guess when I think back of this anime, and of how I felt at that moment when the sound and images used to emerge in front of me, I can never really remake or rewrite the feel of my experience. It's as if I would get overwhelmed if I tried to do it. Taken into a push, mystic, every snow flake around, impossible for me to catch all at once, whether it be with my ears, eyes or hands.


I wish to add as well that you might want to come back to read this review once you've experienced the piece on your own. In the hope that I can share my feelings.

Kuzu no Honkai is a very mature (basicaly soft-core porn) romance anime set in high school (duh!). In very first episodes you can notice that this is not your average slice of life rom-com with very light and mostly only hinted actual romance.
First impression that this show made on me was quite good, good enough to write my original 9 out of 10 review where I praised finally handling romance rom-com differently. It isn't most genious story out there, simply two high-schoolers having kinda weird crushes so they decided to be each other's substitutes. The way how together withfantastic art and music portlayed it was unique at least. The cast doesn't act as 12 year olds blushing and getting embarrased. Well, actually there is not a lot of anime having so much of intimacy as this.


But is this alone enough for a good anime ? Nope.


After first episodes made you feel very excited about all the possibilities this anime could go, as each new episode, I got more bored and dissapointed. When I initially praised anime for it's way of handling romance, I don't know that this will be only thing handled here and how poorly when inital suprise of "wow they actually kissing" wear off.


I mean seriously, you won't find anything else here. 100% of runtime consist of static characters just talking or thinking about who to f*ck, if they are not doing so. Super-clever looking monologue doesn't help making story deeper than this.


It also won't help that initial pretty innocent premmise of woman MC "I like A but I can't be with A so I will seek banging in B" became in the middle "...So I will date B but I will meanwhile I go to bed with C because why not (yuri FTW!) and will try to f*ck D and make him fall for me and meanwhile A and B..."

Story (9)
The plot is interesting, unconventional and well paced. I enjoyed it a lot, but it is not everyone’s cup of tea. 
Characters (10)
We tend to present ourselves in ways that make us look more socially acceptable than we are. Kuzu no Honkai is a good reflection of this. The characters look like ordinary, mild mannered individuals, and yet, they think ugly thoughts and behave in scummy ways. This might sound off-putting to some people, but it’s both realistic and fascinating. Although they look like typical anime tropes (the aloof dark-haired girl, the generic bishounen), the characters are all startlingly human.  
Art (10)
The artis beautiful, with clean lines and nice colours. What makes it really stand out is the symbolism hidden inside. For example, the inkblots in the ED depict sexual imagery in a surreal, artsy way, similar to what you would see in a Rorschach test. You can see Hanabe’s side profile emerge from a splotch that looks suspiciously like a bright pink vagina, which is pretty... interesting. Everything is left open to interpretation, and these kinds of touches help add a whole new dimension of madness and perversion to the show. \n\n
Sound (7)\n
The voice acting was good. OP and ED are both decent as well.\n\n
Enjoyment (9)\n
Hell, I liked it so much that I went ahead and finished the manga. The characters can be scummy and sometimes they behave in ways that make you want to tear your hair out, but this show is definitely worth a shot. \n

SCUMMY. DISGUSTING. APPALLING. 
Turn away from this series if you have a weak heart, or stay and feast your eyes if you are brave and open, to question and view the trashy side of life.
What can be more regrettable and despising than performing acts of love with another person that one has no feelings for; using the other party as a substitute for the one's own perverted and deep (innocent or not) desires? Make that feeling mutual and voila, you have the basic plot for Kuzu no Honkai.
#STORY 9/10
Plot in short (What you need to know):
The MCs Mugi and Hanabi both have unattainable and hopelessloves for the ones they love. Both lonely souls end up dating each other and doing ecchi    (﻿ ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°) acts to each other to fill that void created by their unattainable loves. Things don't get better from there, especially with more characters with their own desires and unique insecurities get thrown into the mix as the story unfolds.

//Note that there will be kissing and sexual(ly suggestive) scenes. (Heck, the first episode has a kiss scene in the first few minutes), if you're not comfortable with such stuff, please refrain from watching! 


WHATS GOOD ABOUT IT?

This series carries very heavy, uncomfortable and mature themes with it. 

It's one of the few anime series that can (and will) disturb your soul.


The story is unique and will bring out the very dark and uncomfortable side of the lustful and selfish desires that humans have that no one wants to see. 

The story is crafted masterfully, such that you will likely experience conflicting feelings (mostly being turned on and disgusted. Additional feelings include being: confused, angry, empathetic, guilty, etc [add for flavouring] ). 

Character development in the story is done well too, with each episode bringing out new contexts and motives of each character, changing the inter-character dynamics and advancing the slightly illogical narrative. (The narrative's momentum is crafted along the character's feelings which to me made the narrative/expository it was trying to portray slightly odd and illogical)


The best thing to me about the story is that it will open your eyes to an under-thought and under-looked range of topics, forcing you to think, or at the very least FEEL the pain and discomfort that the darker side of human desires can result in. If you love thinking and philosophy, this anime is really worth watching and understanding. 


Really not your typical romance anime. (Not the romcom that we're all familiar with)


#ART 8/10


The story and characters are brought to life in a manga-like style of animation, and the way the anime is drawn is oddly satisfying and warm (not your crisp moe kyoani style). I love it, and you may very well love it too.


#SOUND 9/10


The BGM and SFX are masterfully applied to each scene to really bring out many scenes' emotional weight. It really helps with enhancing and adding tension, uneasiness and melancholy just to add to your already thick mix of emotions from the story itself. The OP is also 10/10 <3. The sound from the anime is good enough to compete with NagiAsu and Amanchu's BGM (both I personally think the BGM is 10/10).

Also, masterful voice acting that really bring out the emotions of the characters. 


#CHARACTER 8/10


The character development in Scum's wish is quite well done. As scummy and trashy the characters can be, you can still empathize and somewhat understand their emotional pain and baggage they carry.

I'm not sure about you, but I oddly despise yet love (and sympathize) the characters (most of them). This conflicting feeling towards characters can be hard to come by in most anime.


However, the slight beef I have with Kuzu no Honkai's characters is that at times I honestly cannot get a firm grip on how the characters think BUT, their motives and actions are largely based on their various needs and insecurities (be it a severely sadistic disorder or a simple need for affection and love). //Oh my, I'm droning on at this point


Personally, I felt quite attached to one or two of these characters although I did despise parts of them.

In particular, I would really want to have a heart to heart talk with Hanabi to straighten out her insecurities. They all need counselling and therapy.



#ENJOYMENT 7/10

The enjoyment you get out of this anime is not like what you get from watching Yuru Yuri or Your Name. You may not enjoy its plot and/or characters, but there is just something so intriguing and addictive to this anime that makes you come back for more (even if you feel uncomfortable or distressed). 



#CONCLUSION 9/10

All in all, Kuzu no Honkai (as of ep5) is a masterfully done anime that brings to light the aspects of life (mainly the feelings related to love and lust) many try to suppress and/or hide. It is really worth watching if you're up for it, as it's a really rare gem in the flood of anime that comes out nowadays. Kuzu no Honkai will challenge and go beyond your moral compass and comfort zone.

The biggest satisfaction is when a show knows what it wants to be and it fully shoots for it. There are no gimmicks, no distractions, and it keeps mostly the same tone throughout. I was mostly fascinated by how the show was made around the characters. From start to finish, there is tons of inner monologue that completely goes into the thinking of the characters. It is done in a way to actually not feel like dumb info dumping, but has a nice tonal switch between thoughts left for interpretation, and thoughts that could easily be taken for granted. By keeping such structure you could say it goes deep. Having this form of character introductions by having more than enough material could mean that the characters are complex and have depth.


 While in those thoughts or carefully planned words between characters, you're being shown an interesting aesthetical trick which beautifully invokes their thoughts. Simply put, Kuzu no Honkai was one of the hardest anime to rate in my recent memory. 
It's over-dramatic. Character's actions are illogical and unrealistic. The dialogue can often come across as being too deep and pretentious for its own good. Basically, it has a lot of what I hate in an anime. So why is it that it hit me so hard when I'd finished it? Why could I not stop thinking about it for the rest of the day?
It was a case of head vs heart. When I'd finished it, my head immediately told me to put it down as a 5/10, whichI objectively did. However, throughout the day, all I was thinking about was how I loved the intimate and confrontational moments where the "Scum's Wish" OST grew louder until that final silent drop. How I missed some of the endearing and interesting conversations between characters, despite being in a setting full of irrationality. It wasn't relatable at all and isn't a good representation of love life for the most part, but it was convincingly real enough to spark strong emotions within me.


In summary, Kuzu no Honkai did a great job of tricking me into ignoring its big faults and remembering it for its stunning execution in regards to its frequent hard-hitting moments. It's a contradiction to say this considering the flaws I've pointed out, but the show somehow just felt very human. 


***I'll go into a bit more depth (spoiler free) on how I felt about each aspect to clarify my polarizing view a little more***


STORY: 5/10


Honestly, the story isn't anything special at all. I really wish that it would have focused solely on the struggles of the two main characters Hanabi and Mugi, but instead we get a growing chain where others are dragged into the heart-break abyss. Very little growth can be seen in Hanabi and Mugi as the story progresses, but this is because they already seem somewhat headstrong from the start and completely aware of not only their own emotions, but others as well. Most of the growth comes from the side characters who are sucked into the situation, which feels a little misplaced. A lot of the story revolves around Hanabi and Mugi's quest for an individual to comfort them, and to prolong the closure they require to move on from the person that they truly love. In actual fact, there isn't much of a story at all -  Kuzu no Honkai relies more on the dialogue between characters.


ART: 7/10


The art is simple but effective. I don't have much to comment on it except that it's pleasing on the eye and portrays the emotion of the characters well. 


SOUND: 9/10


This was the real shining light of Kuzu no Honkai for me. A sign of a great soundtrack is when you hear it and instantly remember the scenarios it was paired with and how impactful they were because of it. In general, all of the music was good, but there is a particular song in it which I believe in English just translates to "Scum's Wish." The sorrow and suspense in that song is what made a lot of the scenes in the anime feel real and believable to me, blinding me to the flaws I hate within it. Of course that isn't an objective view, but enjoyment is driven largely by emotion after all. 


CHARACTER: 7/10


I really like Hanabi and Mugi so this aspect would be higher if not for the fact that I felt nothing for any of the other characters. There is a certain charisma with both of them that made it enjoyable to watch their interactions. I love how perceptive they are of other people, and how there's no beating around the bush when it comes to knowing how they feel. I love the brief moments of humour in them even though they're both in depressive states. I love how they don't awkwardly fumble around each other and their dialogue feels meaningful most of the time. I said it before and I'll say it again, it felt convincingly human, even though they're surrounded by illogical and unrealistic plot-lines and actions.


ENJOYMENT & OVERALL: 7/10


It's not a stretch to say that Hanabi and Mugi, along with the music, completely carried this anime for me. I think the potential in it was big, there was just too many other let downs. Although, these factors were still enough to make me really enjoy it and give it an overall of 7. Admittedly, it would be hard to recommend this to people, as it is so dependent on being able to extract enjoyment from areas that you really love to compensate for its issues. But there is no harm in giving it a go.

Love is a difficult topic, one where there is often no right answer amidst a whirlpool of emotions. Kuzu no Honkai is a cautionary tale about unrequited love and the lengths that some will go to make themselves feel "whole".  It is often difficult to quantify WHY you feel a certain way and even harder to justify the actions you take. The characters of Kuzu no Honkai perfectly exemplify the listlessness lack of direction that comes with depression. Kuzu no Honkai is certainly not a perfect anime, and it is incredibly hard to watch, even more so if you are able to relate tothe characters, yet that discomfort is precisely what makes Kuzu no Honkai special. The melodrama, while not realistic, spoke to me, evoking memories of worthlessness and unfulfilled wishes. I didn't enjoy a single moment of Kuzu no Honkai, yet I found myself unable to stop watching, pining for more after the final episode ended. KnH strives to make you feel absolutely horrible in the same way as the characters feel and is that regard, I feel KnH is truly exceptional. Kuzu no Honkai is certainly not for everyone, and I strongly advise against watching if you have depressive tendencies.


Story (8/10):

Nothing terribly exceptional aside from the intent to wear down the viewer with depressing event after depressing event. Contains several contrivances that somewhat detract from the experience. 


Art: (10/10):

I'm not quite sure how to put it, but the art is gorgeous to me. In particular, the emotion that is conveyed through character's eyes is so incredibly powerful, most notable in Hanabi's eyes fluctuating between hope, sorrow, and melancholy. 


Sound (9/10):

The OST is fabulous, Masaru Yokoyama is exceptionally talented at conveying emotion through music, most notably in his work on Shigatsu Wa Kimi No Uso. Kuzu no Honkai is no different, and though occasionally repetitive, the soundtrack compliments the anime exceptionally. 


Character (7/10): 

I feel this is where Kuzu no Honkai receives the most criticism, and rightfully so. The characters act irrationally and without communicating precisely because they ARE irrational and unable to communicate. None of Hanabi or Mugi's actions are out of character or even unreasonable for someone so young struggling with depression. The REAL issue lies with Minagawa and Narumi, the unrequited loves. They are both incredibly flat and incredibly over the top to serve as foils for each other. Without getting into spoilers, Minagawa is so incredibly over the top it often pulled me out of the experience and left me wondering if her character existed solely to generate conflict. Sanae and Moka, while annoying at times, are much more palatable, and offer somewhat compelling character arcs that develop Hanabi and Mugi quite well. Every last character could be the titular "scum", and it is those very flaws that make them unique characters. 


Enjoyment (3/10):

I hated every minute of Kuzu no Honkai, yet I watched it in one sitting without a break. I have not one fond memory of this anime, yet I can't help but go back and listen to the soundtrack. I despise Minagawa yet can't help but feel she is the character that makes KnH so memorable. It's difficult to quantify my enjoyment because of this, but I ultimately decided that KnH is not something you watch to enjoy but to experience. 


Overall (9/10):

Kuzu no Honkai is not for everybody, but if you are able to empathize with the characters is offers a unique experience that not much other anime do.

What?
	• The manga for this was created by an up-and-coming teenage mangaka, so the reason that the story falls on its face and the characters seem so shallow may be the folly of youth. 	• NTR’ing seems to have garnered fame in the anime world, because everyone is getting off to cheating or being cheated on, I guess? 	• There’s an internal monologue with Akane from Scum’s Wish, but it doesn’t really justify her actions.
