I mean, this is a series trying to deliver what the definition of love is and we all know love is scarily subjective. No onereally have a true understanding or meaning to love, not even when we are 78 year olds and have been married for half a century. No, we don't truly know love but we are always constantly learning new things about love. We as human beings yearn to love and be loved, so we learn to love and be loved. Constantly, always. 


Plot:


That's Kuzu no Honkai's story. It's not a fluffy love story or a tragic melodrama, it's kind of in between. Yes, it's like a small window to real life and human relationships.


It's built on making mistakes from wanting to be loved, to consequences from loving someone much like we do in life. Whether it be during our adolescents or our first love, whether it be a form of naivety that we did not once understand. 



It must be a sad thing to have fall so deeply in love with someone but to have it not ever happen. 

That's the whole premise of Kuzu no Honkai.


It's actually a simple story when you break it down, there are four main characters(or five if we go on a little stretch) and all of them really just want to find happiness through love. What happens in the next 12 episodes follow the eyes of this characters as each of them goes through their life and relationships to understand what it is they want out of love and out of their relationships. 


Their definition of love sometimes parallels one another but most of the time their expectations of love are different from one another. Almost all of the characters have a hole to be filled and they seek to constantly feed that hole, even while edging on the brink of what is considered to be morally correct and wrong. 


You probably shouldn't approach this series with rose tinted shoujo glasses but I know you are not here for that. This series is not a dark romance but does a good deal in shedding light on the twisted thoughts people can have - be it intentionally or not. You might come to hate the characters or grow to love them but you will not be able to deny that when you are in any one of their shoes, there's a high chance you would do the same. It's not twisted as much as it is human.



Kuzu no Honkai manage to break down the whys of the character actions. The character monologues are wonderfully weaved to be relatable to the audience. Even when their actions are contradictory on the surface, the anime makes sure you understand that no- it's not that much of a conflict in their actions and emotions after all.  There's something beautiful and absorbing about the way the monologues form a narrative in the story on many occasions. 



There's no strong "climax" nor is there a constant flow of angst drama. But there is resolution for every character and well written development. It's a character driven plot but the storyline never ever lends itself to be overly carried by any character. That's how it always should be, no one should take centre stage. Life happens because everyone is struggling on their path and a story is form at the right point in time when all their paths connect. Kuzu no Honkai did a good job holding back on that despite the many ways it could turned out to be. 


Characters:


I'll just write about the two leads because they are what I feel, the primary focus and should be enough to draw anyone in to watch. 


Hanabi is an endearing character. She's almost, almost like a canvas. It's not like she's a naive girl or a pure white state but she is good will in her thoughts and she is a kind girl that is just trying to have someone love her back. Her character development is one of the highlights of the show. Despite so many times when her character could have gave in and she could become a very much different character(or worse), she always seem to get back on the right path. That's an unwavering will in a sense. I don't think many could have thought the same as her when exposed to the kind of circumstances. Without spoilers, in a sea of choices where it would be far more advantageous to her to take an easy way out she is the kind of character that while appearing fleeting is actually strong willed. That is to say, she rather grow up than to take the easy way out. 



Mugi, on the other hand, is a representation of adolescent boys. He's not kind or nice in any measure nor is he actually downright evil or a manipulative when it comes to love. Like Hanabi, he wants to be love and to seriously love someone.  He's a good insert character if you were a hot dude but honestly, I didn't think most of us are. That's not to say he's unrelatable. Breaking him down, there's a lot of aspects to Mugi that's like us and like boys. For instance the idea of wanting to be the only hero to save the damsel in distress, the desire to be wanted by pretty girls, adolescent frustration and desire all packaged into one. I'm sure we all guys felt like him at one point of our life. What this series does is show us one perspective of how such a character, and like all of us, could grow from this flaws into a better person. 



The characters are great on their own but keep in mind that their interactions are the ones that make this series shine. The other two(or three if we are willing to go a little further) are also well written characters with their own motivations and complexity in them. Although for one of them, I would say their complexity lies instead in being too simple a person(it's not that much of a contradiction once you finished this series, trust me) .



Art/Animation:


The manga uses darker ink and lines but the anime have a more Shoujo-esque and watercolour approach to it which I really like. I think that's how it should be. Need I mention that the art is gorgeous to look at? The characters are beautiful too.


Music:


Easy contender for the season's best OP/ED. Even if the negative reviews keep harping on and on, they'll never let this one be a bad point because the opening and ending complements the story so well and is so good that I actually started this series because of the ending by Sayuri. 



Overall thoughts:


I won't say it's up to your taste to try this or not and that it's a cup of a tea thing because it's really not. In my eyes, Kuzu no Honkai is a window to inevitable problems we will face in our life. The problem and the subject of love is not restricted to this two adolescents but instead can widely apply to anyone who constantly seek the answer to the question of love. There might never be an answer and that is probably true but Kuzu no Honkai is what it is, a wish, no matter how scummy, to desire the answer. And even if you are wrong or even if you fall, maybe sometimes it's all about moving forward to try again. True love is out there, afterall.

A specific question should be answered when watching Kuzu no Honkai:  WHY DO YOU LOVE? Presenting, the pathophysiology of how love can go wrong and specifically, the scumbag disease - that is what Kuzu no Honkai generally is.  Some thought that this is the second coming of an anime that gone in the end (SD) which is certainly not however, let me tell you this, if you want to know a reason of how it could turn out like that SD anime or just want to prevent a love like that happen to you in real life, Kuzu no Honkai is a must-seeanime.


Story:

Hats off to the depth that the story portrays.  I mean, I was expecting that it wouldn't go well to some mangas that are given anime, I feel that it took its liberty to wittingly compress it into 12 episodes without giving too much from the manga and just subtly giving the overall motivation of the character on why they love this other character.  I was also expecting that feeling of dissatisfaction but there wasn't.  Of course, some of us would tell otherwise if they've read the ongoing manga but I'm really glad that I haven't and I could say that I'm happy to how they end the anime.  Because, given that they have ended the characters on how some of us want to ship it or not, I feel Kuzu no Honkai conveyed the message perfectly to the viewers:  Loving like this wouldn't work, would hurt you and would only trigger the cycle.  I applaud Kuzu no Honkai for that.  Whether the truth is subtly or blatantly slapped on your face, morale lesson delivered.


Characters:

I like how the characters are presented to to me a a viewer because of how much they made an impact on me.  Like the female teacher, for example. Sure, I hate this kind of person to the core but at the same time, they gave them enough reason on why she turned out that way and therefore I sympathize on her (well, a little) and I also do feel the same for the other characters to the extreme.


Another thing is, I like how each characters represent a specific type of motivation in why they love.  For example, the character Kamamobeta, do you know what kind of motivation she represent? Do you know why she dressed in a wedding gown at the last chapter's fashion show?  The characters are simply deep and realistic.  I don't see why one argue that they are taken to the extreme.  No, there are people whose motivation in love are like that, consciously or subconsciously, sad to say.  The way each episode's story flows, the flashbacks, their self-reflections/thought processes and how their motivations are changed, I could therefore conclude that they effectively designed the character because these triggered my emotions. Each are effectively compelling. 


Art:

No one could deny that the art is great.  I specifically like how each of the characters eyes are drawn as it changes from being alive to dead.  The eyes are made distinctively blank as if to let the viewers know that they are unmistakably empty.  Also, the ED song's background art is so amazing especially the kaleidoscope part where they presented the lovers.  It's just smartly done.


Sound:

Great voice acting and I think the guys would definitely agree (high five).  It's so stimulating.  The OP and ending is so catching visually and acoustically.  Although I don't know the specific genre (must be pop rock) the OP is very lively and the ED is moving.  The music animation is appropriate.  Actually, I was even moved when I read the lyric english translation of the ED at the last episode.  I think it's just appropriate and it's beautiful. I think if an anime with managed to make me remember the music, it is good indeed.


Enjoyment:

It is not a surprise that the majority of the viewers are not comfortable with Kuzu no Honkai's story.  I for fact is a little uncomfortable; however, although it is really a stimulating and compelling anime, I only opened my mind and took note note of the story and its genre and I considered that this should it not a big problem for me.


Overall:

Thumbs up!  Add it with my teary eyes for special effects.  As one might argue that some characters have gone to the extreme of being a scumbag.  Maybe it's because they are uncomfortable of some "scenes",  still hasn't explored certain topics in real life (failed relationships, sex, etc.) or expecting a fairy tale happy ending (like Kamamobeta, one of the characters).  Such is life. However, the story and the characters with a perfect touch of arts and music are enough to make me want to watch more and see how the story is developed.  I want to know their motivation, what will happen to them in the end,  and how the cycle could end  and this is exactly why I feel this is a good anime to start and end with the question:  WHY DO I LOVE?

After watching a bunch of cliche rom-com animes, Kuzu no Honkai was like a breath of fresh air to me. Strangely enough, this air wasn't fresh one, but rather full of scum. Is that a bad thing? Not necessarily!
Let's start with the story. Just as an aside, when I first heard the plot and watched the first episode, my friends and I called it "emo Toradora." This anime is not very plot-driven. Essentially, a bunch of people trying to work out their feelings for each other. Sounds pretty much like any other romance anime, right? Well, scummy things happen and those of you who likedrama will get some sort of kick out of the happenings of Kuzu no Honkai. If you don't like angst, the story is kind of meandering.


Next, the art. The art was unique, I'll give it that. The art was kind of like a blend of pastels, with gentle, flowery colors. Oh man, the amount of flowers and petals and stuff in this show. Then you got the fade to ink black cuts that provided a nice contrast. Overall, it was unique and portrayed the lighter and darker moments pretty well. I prefer a cleaner sort of style, but I could see what they were going for. It stuck out from the other animes I've been watching recently, so bonus points for that.


Moving on to the characters, which were the driving force for the whole anime. There's the main cast of four, with Hanabi being the main character. That's how it starts out, at least. We get a good idea of each person's story, personality, and world-view through their own eyes, one at a time. Things happen between them, and things change. It's interesting to watch unfold. Certain characters are extremely interesting and fleshed out, and others are briefly and awkwardly introduced. They all react poorly in the face of the drama that takes place, which was a hoot for me. The characters, their actions, and their views are realistic, which is great. Once again, if you don't like angst, you won't like any of these characters.


Finally, the sound. The music throughout the anime is fitting, though nothing really stood out as great. What got a 9 out of me was the OP and the ED. Well, the OP was good. But the ED. That song is gosh-darned amazing. The way that they gently start to play it near the end of the episode was always well-timed and the message of the song is quite fitting for the show. The first few times I heard it, I wrote it off, but the guitar leading into the ED and the ED itself finally hit me. Needless to say, I bought the CD/DVD of the ED. Great song.


I enjoyed the heck out of Kuzu no Honkai. The story can be dumbed down to something like "Scum interact with other Scum," but I rather enjoyed the drama. I also have no shame when I say I enjoyed the amount of sexual content in this anime. It was done in a tasteful way, anyways, and it never got lewd enough for me to go "OK, this is just fanservice." If seeing a bra gives you a nosebleed, go watch something more wholesome like Toradora.


Since I was getting bored of cliche romance animes, like to watch people suffer as a result of their own actions (this is real life, bich), and love great music, I give Kuzu no Honkai a solid 8.

Scum's Wish (Kuzu no Honkai) is a fantastic anime about terrible people. Its story is surprisingly deceptive, and surprisingly headstrong in its delivery. Scum's Wish will take no prisoners, and it's not afraid to show you a world that's more like our own than any I've seen in anime to date. 
To cover all the necessary aspects beforehand: Scum's Wish has a decent - perhaps even moderately good - soundtrack. Its music complements each scene well with dramatic effect and necessary tonal shifts. Its art style is more unique than most, engaging with in-screen boxes and out-of-sync sound bites, although I must admit that, likemost anime of its kind, it falls into the trap of making almost all of its male characters virtually identical. That said, the cast is small enough - a point I'll return to - that this isn't an issue. Its voice actors are all very well chosen, and their internal monologues are a particular highlight, as the anime lets you gradually uncover the changing and evolving personalities of these characters. 


To talk about something more interesting, though: the characters. As I mentioned, Scum's Wish is about terrible people. There won't be anyone here you'll like, there won't be anyone to sympathise with, but the anime dances so dangerously close to making every character sympathetic that it's sort of mind-boggling. The story as it's laid out on screen is that the main characters, Hanabi and Mugi, are both in love with people who love someone else, but in reality, it's more of a chain. Hanabi (who is loved by Sanae) loves Narumi, who loves Akane (who is loved by Mugi (who is loved by Noriko)) who loves no one but herself. It's complicated. Of all these characters, it's Akane that I find most interesting, and I feel that besides Mugi and Hanabi, she has had the most development: she's so unlikeable, but there's so much truth and substance to her character, she's probably the most real of all. With the cast at its current size - the aforementioned and two or three occasional extras - the room for development is vast, and Scum's Wish fully engages with growing and changing characters. Unlike so many anime, which take a two-dimensional character with one specific trait and run with it, the characters in Scum's Wish are genuinely affected by their surroundings. Hanabi especially graduates her initial feelings of self-doubt and loneliness, and even shifts her focus from Mugi to Ecchan (Sanae) to Akane between episodes. Scum's Wish isn't afraid to explore themes very prevalent in our own world, and by taking the worst of humanity and exploiting it, the show conveys an important moral message. 


That's not to say it isn't without its flaws. For all its moral worth the anime borders on being carefully-moderated pornography at times, and the excess with which sexual themes appear is both an advantage and a disadvantage. To explore the negatives first: sex and the dreaded word "fanservice" are bandied about in Scum's Wish to such an extent that the viewer begins to filter them out; sure, it's going to appeal to some people, but it's what ELSE happens in the show that's stimulating to watch. However, as with other points I've made, I feel like Scum's Wish is daring to make that leap that so few anime creators dare to take. What I mean by this is, and I'll be frank here, sex is common in the real world. Whether we want to admit it or not, kids at Hanabi and her peers' age will be thinking about and perhaps even actively participating in sexual activity. I think the show is risky in its potentially encouraging such acts, but it takes an unspoken truth and runs with it: in this twenty-first century, relationships are becoming more and more meaningless as dating apps and websites take over our romantic lives and dictate to us who we should like and how much. In this twenty-first century, people hook up all the time and no one bats an eye. So when the characters in Scum's Wish end up cheating on each other more times than I care to count, it's not even really cheating. It's just the accepted norm today. 


Scum's Wish is well worth the watch. I've tried to keep this review as spoiler-free as possible, but spoilers aren't really an issue in an anime of this kind. It's a wholly untraditional, wholly modern and somewhat macabre take on relationships in the real world, uniquely presented, that sounds better than average, and tries to teach its audience that moral message I mentioned earlier: love isn't perfect. It isn't all it's made out to be, so make it what you want it to be.

“Kuzu no Honkai” or “Scum's Wish” is a show that effectively lives up to its name. Released somewhere in the messy schedule of 2017's seasonal shitfest, a time when I was still with more dignity to even consider diving into the cursed land of seasonal Anime, but it was just a matter of time until I picked it out of my plan-to-watch list.
Honestly, if it wasn't for the nostalgic ending song that I happen to have heard during its release, it would have been still buried in my endless list to an unnamed day, and oh boy did it still disappoint at the end.
- Story(4/10):

A Plot you say? Nowhere to be found, or at least, not one that makes sense anyway. I would have probably settled down with rating it a “0/10”, but given the consideration of nitpicky things it did remarkable right, it was going to be a cruel judgment in its right.

How do I put this in words?! It was as if the poor contributors of this lost cause of a story were cursed with a savage beast from the underworld, equipped with a pointy baton that kept smashing every sense of plot there is to smithereens and everything related, ending up wasting a plotline of great premise (and unfortunately, poor execution).

It all started when two naive high schoolers started hooking up as a sort of medicine they had to take to cure the depression that came from their crushes never accepting their feelings for them. Would they be able to heal their scars at the end?

A truly appealing premise with somewhat of a sense of identity that doesn't follow the common mainstream formula of storytelling and provokes a lot about taboo relationships and lost pride to a youthful lust that doesn't know the way (It's been a year since that meme was a thing, get over it).

Along the lines of using a creative visual rule to lay out the story (more on this later), it was complimented with a yet unique approach that revolved around telling the story through different monologues of the characters involved that helped bring everything full circle, giving you a sense of satisfaction after you see every scenario from different perspectives.

It was somewhere midway where everything broke down like a terrible train wreck that you'd think the writer was barely having a cohesive thought process and still wrote down whatever came in mind with no consideration to common sense like a damn drunkard that literally every episode becomes like a taunting fever dream.


- Art (8.7/10):

On the surface, it's apparent that “Kuzu no Honkai” is visually distinguishable if you look attentively, you'd notice the rough lines around the edges, especially on the characters, design-wise, they looked really good, perfected modern scribbles that try to stay as Anime as possible all while still trying to keep the realism most of the Anime lack visually.

But that was not the reason it was so self-defining at all, the Manga-like lay out on some of the scenes do leave a great mark on the show that tells it apart, having a static background behind a two highlighted face close up Manga-style does leave room for so much more symbolism and a great breather for the overall animation.


- Sound (9/10):

Let's get the minor things away, the voice acting was decent, I really liked Hanabi's voice actress, going with a perfect tone of voice, while the rest of the case was pretty average, aside from maybe Akane's. But man, did I hate Moca's high pitched voice that screams of a childish loli.

The opening song was good, but not half a quarter as good as the ending is, and as I stated, a fantastic vocal performance that's the reason I decided to finally watch the show for.

There goes another bad adaptation that has fantastic vocals (The same as “Taboo Tattoo” and its undeserved opening song).


- Characters (3/10):

Quite a shallow over dramatic cast if I have ever seen one.

Let's start by labeling every single one of them as a “Scum”, don't you love it when a show is that much self-aware that it says it in the title?

Probably the most uninteresting, contradicting and hypocritical group of characters out there. If the plot is to blame for 70% of flaws surrounding this show, the characters can take the other 50%, I know, that doesn't add up to 100%, because it's how much sense this show make anyway.

This was an example for a show that had a faster plot than the characters can keep up with, you'd be expecting even the slightest character development after a certain event, but no, not even after you, as a viewer, read all of the hints they let out and thinking, oh, logically, X is going to be the outcome, oh, let me stop you right there, scum and logic have nothing in common.


- Enjoyment (8.5/10):

Despite the many lows in there, there was a reason I sit through this in 2 days straight, although, I was starting to get fed up of the overly dramatic turnouts nearing the conclusion of the story.

I had quite the laugh on some parts, and even nearly sympathized with some characters, but not after the plot turned its back on me giving me the middle finger.


- Overall (6.64/10):

I'm not sure if this is a recommendation entry in my book, if you were looking for any of the five rules of thumb that makes a show watchable (listed above), then you see how bad this one scales up, although, if you can settle with some drama that you won't have to take seriously, this is one hell of a guilty pleasure that I probably will never end up rewatching.

Kuzu no Honkai is a special case for me. I'm personally a sucker for drama and romance anime, so naturally I'd see this as right up my alley. However, the more I watched it, the angrier and more saddened I became. Saddened not because of the plot, but because of the animation that just doesn't do this anime justice. At first glance, anyone can tell this show has detailed and brightly colored art. At first glance, anyone would say the animation is good. However, that isn't the case. The colorful animation might work in stills, but the way theanime handles the animation is deplorable. If I could pick one phrase to describe how the animation affected my watching experience, I'd pick "immersion breaking." Kuzu no Honkai likes to use layered panels over the frame. This is the main gripe I have with Kuzu no Honkai. Many people would look at it and think "moving manga" and they wouldn't be wrong. It's exactly that, but done poorly. It's not quite moving manga in the aspect that it changes nothing and just animates the panels already given, but rather it's the overlapping. When writing a romance drama, the most important thing you need is immersion. You want your audience to be invested in your characters and what happened to them. But most importantly, you want your characters and world to feel real. This is where the animation plays. The use of manga-like panels breaks the immersion and stomps on it's dead carcass. By placing the panels over the frame that's actually taking place, the anime is telling us that the anime is indeed an anime. That might sound like common sense, but imagine watching a really good drama. Imagine watching something terrible happening to your favorite character. You're invested, you care about them. You don't think of them as a bunch of drawings being moved in quick succession, but as a human being with emotions. By making the world around the characters feel fake, the characters will feel fake too. I can't stand to see panels that are just zoom in shots of the character's face if they're already in the shot(it would've been better with just a jump cut). My connection with this fictional world is broken. That isn't the only thing wrong with the animation. This will also do with the panel format. Sometimes there will be not one, but two panels on the frame. Written down, that doesn't sound too bad, but in action it's even worse. It's two different frames layered ontop of another frame. This means there are three focuses of that shot. Once all three frames are introduced, the worse thing you could do is reuse one of the frames so the audience is thinking about which frame is the one talking instead of what's going on in the anime. That might sound like a nitpick, but it really just adds to breaking my immersion. This next one is also a nitpick. The color pallet is a little iffy. Kuzu no Honkai uses this bright pallet. I personally don't think this works well with a romance drama of this ilk. I think it'd work better with a darker more desaturated pallet to match the emptiness of it's characters. Speaking of the characters, they're excellent. Well, except for the loli and the teacher. By episode 6, I forgot the loli existed and the teacher bitch just felt comically evil. "I slept with the man you love, muahahahaha!" The other characters actually have some humanity injected into them. They have human-like emotions and relationships with people. Now I'm going to doubt many people made it to the end of this review, brushing it off as "just some guy nitpicking" but to anyone that made it down here, thank you. A lot of people might be thinking "How can the animation bring your score down so low?" And to that I say, it's all in how much I enjoyed it. The immersion is very important to me, and if it's broken I no longer enjoy the show. I know 6 may be harsh, but it's honestly how I feel about this anime. Kuzu no Honkai, in my books, will remain a solid 6.

Scum's wish is the embodyment of true human nature. Humans are, by far, the biggest hypocrites. Our malevolent nature is kept under control nowadays for a couple of reasons but in certain situations, it goes berserk. This is where Scum's Wish (or Kuzu no Honkai) really shines.
Story: The story itself is not something that we've never heard of. In fact, it is very realistical up to a point and this may be very boring for most of us anime watchers, as we seek to live impossible lives arm in arm with our characters but, this doesn't happen with this anime. The question is: what doesthis anime do perfectly? The answer I found from the first episode is pace. Dear lord, never have I seen such a fluid pace that makes everything fall into the right place at the right time. I could point out a couple of anime that has a well established pace but that's not my intention for this anime because I can't, or rather than that, I'm not able to compare it. That being said, I give the "story" a 10 because of the pacing as the anime is still ongoing as for the real rating will be after the ending.


Art: The story, as most of the viewers think, is dark but the contrast it creates with the visual artwork is addictive. Studio Lerche really outdid themselves with this artwork. The colours are in darker tones, to amplify the vibe that the story gives but the way that they use them is smart. As usual the hair colours of the characters gives us insight of their personalities but it can be misleading. I recommend analyzing their traits through the meaning of colours. Last but not least, every "mature scene" is created in an unique way and I included them here because they are the "spices" for our artistic soup because, without them, this anime's appeal wouldn't be as impressive as it is. Therefore, for the art, no mark is acceptable other than 10, as a sign of respect for Lerche who put so much effort into this.


Sound: I'm going to skip the opening and the ending songs because they're masterpieces (the lyrics have meanings which are found in the story itself) and talk about the soundtracks. This is my main criteria for a good anime because without well picked soundtracks, no anime can get an overall 10 from me. In Kuzu no Honkai, the OSTs are subtle and emphisizes the characters inner thoughts. Most are calm and soothing mostly because of the volume but they are not "special" in some way. But, I gave it a 10. The reason is: best VA ever heard. No matter how great the scene is, if the VA mess up then everything falls to ruins. Voice Acting is important because if the VA doesn't empathizes with the character, they will sound "fake" and the feeling of living through the anime dissapears.


Characters: The only thing that makes them special is realism. The title is "Scum's wish" because they know who they are and what repercussions their actions will have. Their desires are selfish, just like the human nature and they act according to one. For spoiler reasons I will not talk more about them but my personal opinion is: the inner dialogues are top-notch, made with the intention of giving subtle hints about their choises which are not naive or stupid, they are needed for them to survive emotionally. 


Personal enjoyment: As I wait for the next episodes, I think about the possible outcomes from my point of view and that makes it interesting because I've never seen such an anime. Each episode has its glow that shines differently from the others and it feels like watching a well done hollywood love movie. Even if there are mature scenes, there is no need for showing nudity because like the rest of the anime it is full of symbolism which means that you have analyze the aspects that this anime presents you.


Overall Kuzu no Honkai is one of the best anime that this season gave us because this fresh breath of originality will pave the way for more high quality anime for seinen anime.

Anime is not bad. The animation is acceptable. The form of narration is similar to that of a book. The problem lies in the form that approaches unrequited love. It is an intense cultural shock. Even for those who are used to Japanese culture.
Be a replacement, seek affection. Feeling lovely. It is what best describes this anime. As far as we are able to endure in order to get them, to keep them?

It doesn't require someone with a degree in psychology to work out that Scum's Wish isn't for everyone. In fact, it isn't for the majority of people, but for those few who understand the pain of unrequited love, but more precisely, the mental (and sometimes physical) hardship it brings.
When I began to watch this anime, I was impressed at how physical this show got. It reminded me of Elfen Lied, where the anime wasn't afraid to disturb the viewer, and it didn't give a fuck about the viewer in general, or how much it disturbed them.
As for the actual genre, and the type of emotionthis anime gave off, I'd say it is much closer to School Days. Where School Days was unlikeable because of how badly written and cringey it was, Scum's Wish is unlikeable because of how incredibly and uncomfortably honest and realistic it can get.


Both School Days and Scum's Wish have much in common, this can't be denied. However where Scum's Wish stands far above the other, is in the actual characters, even if both casts are scum. 

In the case of Makoto Itou, he manipulated the other girls for his own personal desires. Nothing else. 

However in the case of Hanabi and Mugi, they manipulated others to fill in for their own pain – their own void left behind by the unrequited, failed love between them and their respective crush. During some of the more physical scenes, we truly get to feel their pain and despair, to the extent of which I have never seen shown in anime. These scenes were probably some of the best scenes the anime had to offer, (not due to the nudity, mind you... there are websites for that in particular.) because we got to listen to the feelings and monologues of these characters' emotions and remorse as they went through various sexual activities.


That, is where the show really got to shine. (Or suck, depending on your taste and outlook.)


Most of the characters are truly despicable, even if they are very well-written. Some are sadistic as they cannot get enough of the company of others, some are willing to go through with this just to see others suffer... Either way, the whole cast acts on their extremely selfish nature.


The honesty of this show is spectacular. The characters are shown in very intimate moments with various people, as it tries to explain their scrambled, and confused minds. Experimentation is a common sight among high-schoolers, as that is the period where this confusion is common, especially in terms of sexual orientation – something that this anime highlighted quite well.


This anime gets real, and quickly so. The loneliness that it often shows can be really devastating. It can really show that the even if the faultless relationships in shoujo romances may exist in small numbers, it's the dark side of love that is more commonly experienced – in short, love is a poison. Or a drug, whichever you prefer. It'll give you a high, but sooner or later, you will get hurt. Try to take more, and it will fuck you up. Trying to understand it yields confusion, trying to fight it deals more damage. You can't win against it. It will make you do things that you wouldn't do as a person, including creating rough relationships by physically using your friends as “replacements” for your crush, or having multiple sexual relationships, just to ease the pain. Like I said... it's all a drug.


Is the anime difficult to watch? Yes. Very.


Why?


The reason depends on who watches it. Somebody may find the honesty too much for them, or perhaps the whole extent of the physical relationships too overwhelming. Or those very unlucky few, who can find something to relate to the anime from their former relationships, or worse again, recall bad memories from them. 

Either way, I doubt there is a way you can walk away from this show without feeling at least a bit of misery inside of you, or sadness, or empathy, or whatever other emotion your mind can conjure up after this experience.


Long story short, this anime is heavy. It is hard to accurately comprehend the actions and behaviour of each of the characters, simply because they act based on their lust, and not based on how they think. And it goes without saying that this type of behaviour is hardly ever logical.


I honestly believe that Scum's Wish should be recalled as one of the truly unique gems in anime. 

I'm certain that it can be titled a deconstruction of the romance genre. There is so much more to add to the discussion about Scum's Wish, but it isn't possible to do so in a comprehenisive way. It isn't afraid to stick to the cold, harsh truth, and treads through very sensitive subjects without a care in the world. Unfortunately, many viewers, if not the majority of them, simply cannot understand the complexity behind the anime, and simply dismiss it as the equivalent of School Days Season 2. And then there are those who simply cannot take any enjoyment out of this, for their personal reasons.


A real shame too...
